articles.title: If We Want Bigger Wind Turbines, We’re Gonna Need Bigger Airplanes
articles.summary: The world’s largest airplane, when it’s built, will stretch more than a football field from tip to tail. Sixty percent longer than the biggest existing aircraft, with 12 times as much cargo space as a 747, the behemoth will look like an oil tanker that’s sprouted wings—aeronautical engineering at a ...

articles.title: The Real Story on AI’s Water Use–and How to Tackle It
articles.summary: AI is hot, capturing headlines, investments, and users. It also runs hot, literally: The data centers operating artificial intelligence (AI) models use large amounts of electricity and generate enormous heat. To keep servers from overheating, many facilities rely on cooling systems that use water.AI...

articles.title: Machine Learning Tests Keep Getting Bigger
articles.summary: The machine learning field is moving fast, and the yardsticks used measure progress in it are having to race to keep up. articles.title: How Robotics Is Powering the Future of Innovation
articles.summary: The future of robotics is being shaped by powerful technologies like AI, edge computing, and high-speed connectivity, driving smarter, more responsive machines across industries. articles.title: Natcast to Lay Off Majority of Its Staff
articles.summary: Natcast, the non-profit organization created to run the U.S. CHIPS & Science Act’s National Semiconductor Technology Center (NSTC) told the majority of its staff they would be laid off this week, IEEE Spectrum has learned. A small core team will continue on to shut Natcast down over the next few wee...

articles.title: Reality Is Ruining the Humanoid Robot Hype
articles.summary: Over the next several years, humanoid robots will change the nature of work. articles.title: Help Celebrate IEEE Day on 7 October
articles.summary: Every year IEEE members around the globe come together on IEEE Day to celebrate a shared legacy of innovation, collaboration, and service. articles.title: A Fusion-Reactor-Inspired Thruster Could Deorbit Space Junk
articles.summary: There are plenty of labs working on solutions to Kessler Syndrome, where there’s so much debris in low Earth orbit that rockets are no longer capable of reaching it without being hit with hypersonic parts of defunct equipment. articles.title: How Much Carbon Do We Need to Capture?
articles.summary: Plans to end global warming hinge on driving net greenhouse gas emissions to zero (plus or minus a few gigatonnes). It’s not going well. CO2 emissions hit an all-time high last year, and for the first time average temperatures on Earth rose 1.5 °C above preindustrial levels. To limit warming to 2 °C...

articles.title: Face to Face With the Scale of the Cosmos
articles.summary: For most of us, to see a truly starry night isn’t easy. I have been writing about dark skies and light pollution for almost 20 years.
